lib
Class G

java.lang.Object
  lib.G

public class G
extends java.lang.Object

Class G contains "General utilities, and small static functions that any program may need.

Author:
Dave Dyer

print

public static void print(java.lang.Object... msg)
utility to print test messages, use "find callers" to find messages still in place. This method also interfaces with shells created by the "open shell" menu item. If a shell has been opened, it is used instead of System.out as the output device.

Parameters:
msg -

print

public static void print(java.lang.String msg)

Lock

public boolean Lock()
if the lock is available, lock it and return true

Date

public static long Date()
get the current date. This is synchronized so different threads can't see decreasing times

Returns:
the current time in milliseconds, guaranteed to be monotonically increasing

Time_Cheat

public static boolean Time_Cheat()
return true if the clock has ever been set back. Setting the clock back can be a clever way to try to get extra time, or it can be an accident.

Returns:
true if the time of day has unexpectedly changed

Unlock

public void Unlock()
unlock the lock without checking if we really owned it

wait until it is available and get the lock

drawBubble

public static void drawBubble(java.awt.Graphics inG,
                              int x,
                              int y,
                              java.lang.String msg,
                              java.awt.Rectangle r)
draw a tooltip bubble with the pointer pointing to x,y, constrained to appear in rectangle R. Text may be multiple lines separated by \n The position of the pointer is adjusted appropriately if the x,y is too close to the edges of the rectangle. should be brief.

Parameters:
inG - the graphics to draw
x - the x of the focus of attention
y - the y of the focus of attention
msg - the text to be displayed
r - the bounding rectangle

Assert

public static boolean Assert(boolean condition,
                             java.lang.String message,
                             java.lang.Object... args)
G.Assert returns true, or throws an Error. It provides a convenient place to place a breakpoint for any kind of internally detected error. This should be the only "throw Error" in the system.

Text

public static int Text(java.awt.Graphics inG,
                       boolean center,
                       int inX,
                       int inY,
                       int inWidth,
                       int inHeight,
                       java.awt.Color inColour,
                       java.awt.Color bgColor,
                       java.lang.String inStr)
draw a text string, resized downward if necessary to fit the box. the string may be multiple lines separated by \n if width<0, center the text at xpos without resizing if height=0, center the text at ypos

Parameters:
inG - the graphics to draw
center - if true, center the text
inX - x location of the left edge
inY - y location of the upper-left corner
inWidth - box width
inHeight - box height
inColour - forground color (or null)
bgColor - background color (or null)
inStr - the string to draw
Returns:
the text width

Rotate

public static java.awt.Image Rotate(java.awt.Component who,
                                    java.awt.Image im,
                                    double angle)
call this to rotate an image around its center by an angle in radians. This ignores the right and bottom edges of the input image, because the pixel values the edges of jpeg images are unreliable. The output image is one pixel smaller than the input, and the corners of the rotated image are copied from nearby pixels in the source image. The intended use for this is artwork which has a uniform edge, and enough padding so the interesting part of the image is always inside that edge.

Parameters:
who - the window doing the rotating, or null to create a trashed temp
im - the input image
angle - the angle (in radians) to rotate counter clockwise
Returns:
a rotated version of the input image.

CompositeSelf

public static java.awt.Image CompositeSelf(java.awt.Component who,
                                           java.awt.Image mask,
                                           int component,
                                           java.awt.Image im,
                                           int bgcolor)
call this to pre-composite two rgb images loaded from source files.

Parameters:
who - the component for whom to composite
mask - the mask (with black for parts to keep from the foreground)
component - the shift for the mask (normally 0,8,16)
im - the optional image to be composited
bgcolor - alternatively, the fixed color to composite against
Returns:
a new, composited image
